title: OCULAR RESTRICTION SYNDROMES: A VISUAL CLINICAL ATLAS
summary: Mechanical restriction syndromes represent uncommon but significant causes of strabismus. Predominantly congenital, these patterns involve structural, developmental, or innervational abnormalities affecting ocular motility.

sections.title: Overview of Restriction Syndromes
sections.content: Syndromic patterns of mechanical restriction are uncommon causes of strabismus. They are usually congenital, although later presentations may occur.

branches: Aberrant co-​innervation of LR and MR by IIIn

sections.title: Clinical Features of Duane Syndrome
content: Retraction of globe (with reduction of palpebral aperture) on attempted adduction
± Up-​/downshoots on attempted adduction
Additional features according to specific type (Table 17.10)

content.explanation: Deafness, Goldenhar syndrome, Klippel–Feil syndrome, Wilderwank syndrome (Duane, Klippel–Feil, and deafness).

sections.title: Treatment of Duane Syndrome
content: Assess and treat for refractive error and potential amblyopia
Reassure if managing well with minimal/mild compensatory head posture; most require no further intervention
Consider prisms for comfort or to improve head position
Consider surgery to improve BSV and head position
Surgical standard: Uni-​/ bilateral MR recession for esotropic Duane
Surgical standard: Uni-​/ bilateral LR recession for exotropic Duane

sections.title: CRITICAL SURGICAL CONTRAINDICATION
content: Avoid LR resection in Duane Syndrome
Reason: It increases globe retraction more than it improves abduction

sections.title: Brown Syndrome (Restriction Syndromes 847)
sections.content: This is a mechanical restriction syndrome that Brown attributed to the SO tendon sheath. It appears to arise from structural or developmental abnormalities of the SO muscle/tendon or the trochlea, leading to limitation in the direction of its antagonist (IO) due to apparent failure of relaxation of the SO.

sections.title: Brown Syndrome Timeline & Causes
content: In most cases, it is congenital (or at least infantile)
Usually improves or resolves (at least symptomatically) by 12y of age
Acquired causes: Trauma, surgery (e.g. SO tuck, buckling, orbital), or inflammation (e.g. RA, sinusitis)

sections.title: Brown Syndrome Clinical Features
content: Limited elevation in adduction
± Pain/click (‘click’ often occurs during resolution)
Limited sequelae (i.e. overaction of contralateral SR only)
V pattern
May downshoot in adduction (swan dive)
Positive forced duction test (FDT)

sections.title: Treatment for Brown Syndrome
content: Reassure if managing well with minimal/mild compensatory head posture
Wait for age improvement: Upgaze is less of an issue with patient vertical growth
Surgery: Consider if significant abnormal head posture or if strabismus in 1° position
Surgical Aim: Release restriction (e.g. SO tenotomy) until repeated traction test shows free rotation
Acquired Cause Treatment: Periocular or oral corticosteroids

sections.title: Brown Syndrome Surgical Warnings
content: Surgical results are often disappointing
Complication: SO palsy

branches: Bilateral nuclear VIn and VIIn palsies
May be associated with bilateral tight MR causing restriction

sections.title: Moebius Clinical & Systemic Features
content: Bilateral failure of abduction
May be pure gaze palsy or bilateral tight MR causing esotropia
Positive forced duction test
Bilateral VII palsy (expressionless face)
Bilateral XII palsy (atrophic tongue)
↓ IQ (Decreased IQ)
Digital abnormalities

rows: Bilateral restrictive ophthalmoplegia and ptosis; inability to elevate globes above midline.
Bilateral ptosis, wide angle exotropia, and severe limitation of horizontal and vertical movements.
More variable motility defects and genetic heterogeneity.

sections.title: Pathogenesis of CFEOM
sections.content: This rare congenital syndrome probably arises due to abnormal development of the oculomotor nuclei.

sections.title: Myopic Strabismus Fixus
content: Rare, well-​recognized acquired syndrome seen in high myopes
Eye is often fixed in adduction with hypotropia
MRI findings: Deviated courses of the EOMs, with globe prolapse between LR and SR
Surgery: Ipsilateral myopexy of LR and SR (after Yokoyama) ± MR recession
